soc.message

Class SOCBoardLayout

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCBoardLayout
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, SOCMessageForGame

    public class SOCBoardLayout
extends SOCMessage
implements SOCMessageForGame
    This message contains the board layout information: The hex layout, the dice number layout, and the robber location. Does not contain information about any player's pieces on the board (see PUTPIECE).

    This message sends the classic board layout for the original 4-player game, SOCBoard.BOARD_ENCODING_ORIGINAL. As of version 1.1.08 there are newer board layouts for game expansions and 6-player extensions: SOCBoardLayout2 is sent instead for games with those features.

    Unlike SOCBoardLayout2, the dice numbers are mapped before sending over the network, and unmapped when received. This is because of a change in SOCBoard.getNumberLayout() in 1.1.08, the version which introduced SOCBoardLayout2. Older clients/servers will still need the mapping done, so it's now done here instead of in SOCBoard.

    In v2.0.00 and newer, the hex layout values for WATER_HEX and DESERT_HEX were changed to allow new types of land hex. Just like the dice numbers, this is mapped in the constructor, sent over the network, and unmapped in getHexLayout(), for backwards compatibility with older clients.

    Optimization:

    For v2.0.00 and newer servers and clients (VERSION_FOR_OMIT_IF_EMPTY_NEW_GAME):

    If the game is still forming (state GameState.NEW_GAME), client already has data for the empty board. If so, no board layout message is sent to the client.

    Author:
    Robert S. Thomas
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static int VERSION_FOR_OMIT_IF_EMPTY_NEW_GAME
      First version number (2.0.00) where client isn't sent this message when joining a GameState.NEW_GAME game, because the board is empty and client already has data for an empty board.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCBoardLayout

        public SOCBoardLayout(java.lang.String ga,
                      int[] hl,
                      int[] nl,
                      int rh)
        Create a SOCBoardLayout message. Hex type numbers and dice numbers will be mapped from their game-object values to the old compatibility values sent over the network.
        Parameters:
        ga - the name of the game
        hl - the hex layout; not mapped yet from SOCBoard's value range, so the constructor will map it.
        nl - the dice number layout; not mapped yet, so the constructor will map it from the SOCBoard.getNumberLayout() value range to the BOARDLAYOUT message's value range.
        rh - the robber hex
        See Also:
        SOCBoardLayout(String, int[], int[], int, boolean)

      • SOCBoardLayout

        public SOCBoardLayout(java.lang.String ga,
                      int[] hl,
                      int[] nl,
                      int rh,
                      boolean alreadyMapped)
        Create a SOCBoardLayout message, which may have already mapped hex type numbers and dice numbers from their game-object values to the old compatibility values sent over the network.
        Parameters:
        ga - the name of the game
        hl - the hex layout
        nl - the number layout
        rh - the robber hex
        alreadyMapped - have the hex layout and number layout already been mapped? Callers should use false, except from parseDataStr(String) or certain unit tests.
        Since:
        1.1.08
        See Also:
        SOCBoardLayout(String, int[], int[], int)

    • Method Detail

      • getGame

        public java.lang.String getGame()
        Description copied from interface: SOCMessageForGame
        Name of game this message is for, if any. Must not be null in a message sent to the server: If message is not about per-game structures or code, use SOCMessage.GAME_NONE.

        At the server, the message treater dispatches incoming SOCMessageForGames based on their getGame():

        • null: Message is ignored
        • SOCMessage.GAME_NONE: Message is handled by SOCServer itself or SOCServerMessageHandler
        • Any other game name: Looks for a game with that name, to dispatch to the GameHandler for that game's type. If no game with that name is found, the message is ignored.
        Specified by:
        getGame in interface SOCMessageForGame
        Returns:
        the name of the game

      • getHexLayout

        public int[] getHexLayout()
        Get the hex layout, as mapped from the BOARDLAYOUT message value range to the SOCBoard.setHexLayout(int[]) value range.
        Returns:
        the hex layout

        Returns:

      • toCmd

        public java.lang.String toCmd()
        Formatted string to send this BOARDLAYOUT over the network. BOARDLAYOUT sep game sep2 hexLayout[0] sep2 ... sep2 hexLayout[36] sep2 numberLayout[0] sep2 ... sep2 numberLayout[36] sep2 robberHex
        Specified by:

      • stripAttribNames

        public static java.lang.String stripAttribNames(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a comma-delimited list for SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String). Converts robber hex coordinate to decimal from hexadecimal format.
        Parameters:
        messageStrParams - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters without attribute names, or null if params are malformed
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Render the SOCBoardLayout in human-readable form. In version 1.1.09 and later, the hexLayout and numberLayout contents are included, and for convenience robberHex is in hexadecimal instead of base-10. Returns the same remapped "network" values for WATER_HEX, DESERT_HEX, and dice numbers as toCmd(), not the "standard" ones returned by getHexLayout() and getNumberLayout().
        Specified by:
        toString in class SOCMessage
        Returns:
        a human readable form of the message
        See Also:
        SOCMessage.toCmd()
